payload.session_notes_transcription: that broke it (in response to momentary switch);sick (in response to rate parameter = 0);i find myslef wanting to understand it all, like what each thing is actually doing, rather than play with it; i want it to go real crazy; it is real crazy that; when its stuck and i add a note it plays all the different octaves; i like it wen it feels more random; with all the lights on its like having the inverse of having just a few on - if i couldnt see the visuals i woulnt know if they were mainly on or off; got some real deepness going on there;i feel the need to make nice music, in scale; when it goes crazy its a bit much but doenst matter if noone else is listening; id like to see units next to the parameters (on the control interface); i didnt get caught in the frustrating loops like can happen with modular synthesisers; interesting that im taking ownership of whats happening; input control (with mouse and web control app) is not amazingly tactile/ergonomic, on synths you can just pop a dial back if you make a mistake; in my head it sounded different, I feel like i should have known it would sound the way it did; my perception changes after answering these questions; i feel like im happy to take credit for it doing stuff when it does what i want it to do; (in response to sound only block) it definately feels like something missing, without the visuals it didnt feel like i was really in control;

payload.expectation_vs_outcome:
I initially found this task less satisfying than my first two attempts. I think this is because while I have a basic understanding of the system, different parameters seeem to feed into the same outcome unless rules are followed. 

Despite this I really enjoyed the final playback as there were lots of interesting audio and visual outputs which were partially planned but also unexpected.

payload.one_change: Incorporate A/D/S/R envelopes into the audio and visuals!
payload.reflection:
Creativity can come from not fully understanding the parameters and playing around
Musical knowledge and theory is not required to make music and enjoy the creative process
Using the system I felt like I was experiencing audio and visual as a combined sense opposed to sensing them separately.

payload.expectation_vs_outcome: I had no idea what it would be like so no expectations aside from faster to slower / more > less light. I had forgotten that compaitble colours made compatible tones which is perhaps why I didn't make a 'pleasing' chord/ sound. I did like the way it looked.

payload.strategy: audio focussed, playing with fewer parameters and the scale in search of a more pleasing sound, also the fuller > emptier spectrum

payload.strategy: from a stable-ish pattern (black keys) turning new keys on or off one by one to see how it changed / felt / looked as a whole.

payload.expectation_vs_outcome: I couldn't imagine what it would be like from looking at the light pattern but I liked the sound and the correlations. the nature-like patterns and the shift in feel when adding a new colour, then the chaos broke out but managed to regain composure by the end.

payload.reflection:
For me, the audio had to be removed completely before I could prioritise the visual - the audio was more important to my overall experience - the avoidance of overwhelm and generation of feelings of pleasure or balance.
Audio only was hardest - perhaps also because I did it first,  but perhaps because I had no other reference point to go by. 
I liked the sense of having control yet also being fully in imperfection and play and surprise.
I don't really understand the audio-visual relationship but already more than I did at the start. 
It's magic!
payload.session_notes_transcription: you could just spend hours and hours; with the visuals turned off you have no idea; cant remember what anything does now; everytime i try to loop the whole thing stops; cant get anything to sound vaguely nice, not doing jazz anymore; dont have a choice but ot make something that doens sound nice; still dont understand what the parameters are doing; lets try turning them all on; quite a relief (playing without headphones on) because you know (just by looking that) it would be cacophonous; liked it when that blue note came in;emergence - imperfection to allow yourself to play is a good excercise regardless of output; nice to do it without sound;

payload.perceptual_comments: Using speaker instead of headphones for audio output

payload.strategy:
Find set of parameters that resulted in 'the right' amount of sounds being produced in a given interval
Initially start with a tone set that I thought would work (based on sounds). Change active tones by removing and adding nearby. During task I was influenced by which sounds to activate/deactivate based on the colour combinations being displayed - aiming for hue-similar colours to be simultaneously active.

payload.param_other: Set an initial set of parameters giving rhythmic pattern that felt the right proportion of 'busy' and then changed scale notes.
payload.interference_notes: There were moments (when reviewing the piece) when I was surprised by disonance in note tones despite colour combinations produced.
payload.expectation_vs_outcome: The result was suprisingly interesting/mesmerising, I could feel my brain try to work out the pattern as well as surprise/'delight' as new patterns of chord tones and colour combinations emerged and changed throughout the piece. The colours on the video were not as easily discernable as when looking at the physical instrument. As I am a musician - my association felt more like light was accompanying the sound, although with longer exposure to the instrument this may change.

payload.strategy: Overall strategy was more aimed at achieving pleasant patterns and combinations of colours on the tool (e.g. quickly turning off a colour after turning it on and seeing it doesn't fit). During use of the tool this time I felt like I played more with a narrative associated to the visual display, especially towards the end where I increased the frequency of lights active at one time, followed by an 'ending' which had less and less lights active as the piece was ending.

payload.interference_notes: Length of light activity was misleading for tone length which was shorter and did not match.
payload.expectation_vs_outcome:
I expected the sound to be more dissonant than it was (i.e. a good matching between tones and light combinations - constructive intereference), this is probably related to the lights being kept on for longer than the associated sound was playing. At times (especially from the middle of the piece to the end) I did not find much association between light duration and note duration - destructive intereference.
The shared tonality was surprisingly consonant when colours where matched. When there were dissonant tones playing at the same time, it was more 'interesting' in the sound modality than in the lights modality (e.g. introduction of a green to predominantly purple/red colour combinations).

Overall, the creation of the piece this time was more intuition driven, and I was not 'thinking' about what would sound good given my background music theory knowledge.

payload.strategy: I was aiming for finding pleasant melodies/harmonic movement by individual tones on and off together. I was not focusing on colour matching tones but instead relied on a mixture of trial and error and expectations of what tones would match based on music theory/harmony knowledge.

payload.interference_notes: It felt like at times of low sound activity there were more lights active than expected, although as I said, this was a positive in this instance rather than a negative contributor to experiencing the piece. It was less clear why small changes in scale tones used led to large cascades in near-neighbour activation. Essentially it felt like a set of stable ('solid') states separated by high disorganisation in the states ('gas/liquid' states).
payload.expectation_vs_outcome:
The light modality was more organised than I expected for the majority of the piece, revealing repeated spatial patterns when tones had more pleasing scale intervals. It felt like the pattern of light placements added an extra dimension/dynamicism to the piece, as they shifted between ordered spatially repeating patterns, separated by times of high activity/randomness that corresponded to dissonance and (at those times) overwhelming sound arrangements. 
The spatial extent of the light patterns (how many lights were active at any one time) were surprising given how few notes were playing (between shifts) - this actually added to the experience as one note playing activated multiple lights it created something more interesting to look at.

payload.one_change:
Having a default settings preset on the controller would be useful. Consider having a few presets that correspond to different audiovisual patterns that users can start from.

The scale tone colours in the controller do not match the instrument light colours as closely as I would have liked (especially yellow/green on the G/A side were basically identical in the controller). 

Note length slider does not correspond to the light activity duration (light carries on after note dies out), consider matching these more closely - adding variable light intensity might be a nice way to do this if changing the lights, or matching the tone duration to make it ring out for longer if changing the tones.
payload.reflection:
On watching back the pieces, what felt most satisfying was the close association between sound and light, rather than coherence of the sound to resemble a piece of music (which I expected beforehand). This said, it was important to have some periods of tonal coherence, because it enabled me to focus in on the more static associations (I think just having high activity/dynamics of light and sound would be overhwelming and not satisfying). 
I think that it would be possible to discern (better than at random) which piece corresponded to which modality being available, based on which modality dominated the experience when reviewing the piece. 
Perhaps it is because of habituation to using the tool, but I felt that when both modalities were available (my first attempt), it was in a sense overwhelming to 'compose' with sound and visuals simultaneously, i.e. trying to make them both look/sound good at the same time. However this may have been the settings I was initially using, which I refined in further conditions.
payload.session_notes_transcription: so all the colours are fixed; in complex systems the first thing we do is turn all the parameters to the maximum; some of the colours are very similar on the control panel scale switches;takes a second for the brain to make the association between the colour and the note; taking long to get an intuition of the controls; minimum neighbours is the wrong way round;colours are not easily discerable on the (recorded) video as compared to the instrument (itself);quality of the video will likely influence some of the responses;started withtheory then migrated to using the lights;with visual only i felt less connected to why things were happening;one note changed alot; confident is the key word here - i have no idea how the visual look;hard to say which order i did the videos on the rewatch; question of which piece is better is tricky as for one the audio is better and for another the visuals are better;got better with time;audio was frustrating when chaos/chaotic out of control but on reveal it was satisfying to see the lights; as a creative constraint just focusing on one modality is powerful; bringing in the missing modality helps make sense of the bits that didnt work alone; include visual artists/lighting technicians in the who would this be most sutied to; add chrod presets;

payload.strategy:
Build up busy space and sound.
Find and understand harmonies and chords, understand colour patterns and structures.
Play with notes to build out and understand melodies.

payload.interference_notes: No, however it is possible to witness properties and not understand where they come from or how to control them, within this time frame.
payload.expectation_vs_outcome: I found the the video review revealed more structures than I expected, particularly the light patterns. With only one minute I initially felt that I may not be able to record anything with typical music structure, however the video and sound did have more musical merit than I thought. This is satisflying as someone who does not consider themselves musical. The visual patterns help reveal the relationships between notes.

payload.strategy:
This was more play and experimental.
More a/b testing to understand the properties.
Aim to overall build more sounds.

payload.interference_notes: No, it felt coherant.
payload.expectation_vs_outcome:
The outcome was more satisflying than I felt the recording and playing process went.
It felt harder to control the system using purely sound, I think this is because I am a more visual person, however the build up of sound, even if random was fun and on review had more structure than maybe I realised during the process of recording.
Due to the speed of the lights and output produced, it felt like the sounds and audio had more of an impact. However I felt less in control of the sound during the recording.

payload.strategy:
Fill the whole grid with lights.
Build up a full grid then switch the rate up and down.

payload.interference_notes: No.
payload.expectation_vs_outcome:
I expected to be able to have more control over the system, even without sound. I felt this was the case, it was quite clear to understand the impact of my choices and work towards my strategy. 
I don't think I had a strong idea to how the recording would sound and it did sound chaotic. This chaotic sound was satisfying, less because of any typical musical merit, but more the ability to control this.

payload.one_change: Seeing the colours of the notes, reglardless of them being played may have helped build more harmounious sounds. The circles could indicate the colour even when off. Likewise, for someone who doesn't know music, having addition chord selection, aswell as notes, could have been satisfying for someone who doesn't know these chords normally.
payload.reflection:
The visual structures of sound were more pronounced than I expected.
The relationship between similar colours providing more harmonies was satisfying.
The ability to control the system was greater than my percieved musical skills, however the ability to control the visual block aligned with my ideas of how my brain most effectively processes infomation.
The reviewed videos were more satisfying than I might have imagined. Even if a choatic outcome, having played a part in constructing the light and sound felt like I had some agency and ability to control a somewhat autonomous system.

payload.strategy: a differnet game - brain shift not seeing any visuals - but didnt take long to adapt and get into the sounds world. as soon as the visuals wernt there i really did notice a shift in my engament comapered with audio and visual . really thinking about texture and desity, looping was fundamental, starting wth basic, empty loop, and allowing things to quite slowy become randomised to try and not let go of the loop, keeping it sparse, and then come back to another loop - musical container, some sense of predicatability, how would you make an audience feel safe in this sound - felt like a repetition is how that could be acheived.

payload.one_change: having the panel infront of you than looking down on it from above, would perhaps enable better connection to the instrument. how could we work with beat, more control over rhythm, which is so important - how could you latch on to something rhythmically, and then develop it (rather than loose it very easily)
payload.reflection:
the revealed modality for block B went beyond my expectations and so was the bigest mismatch (positive)
my surprise in B and C - noticing that initial glitch in my experience, taking away the visuals, and not realising just how much that was impacting my learning/playing with the instrument . with C, how having the visuals there opened up my creative process, a letting go of expectation, which is a dream when it comes to creating something, to not be tied up in priducing something

doing it in this order ( A, B, C ) was really good for me / satisfying creative experience for me
payload.session_notes_transcription: hey fun - i like the loop function alot; randomness is so unpredictable; decreasing loop length feels really interesting; im not even looking at the panel (AV block) didnt even think about pitch and what scale notes to use on the visual block;frustration not super high becasue i dont understand what im doing yet fully - my expectations (of what i should be able to acheieve) are lower / havent been set yet;epectation of how good you are at something is dependent on your skilll level, frustration comes with expectation; learning happens when frustration is low; ahh its so pretty (visuals); visuals surpised me with their beauty;satisfaction is intersting as i felt in a playful state so satisfaction higher than if i was in a perfomance /product state;wasnt thinking of it as a performance; we (me and instrument) is the dyad <separte to dyad condition!>; mindset shift - not thinking about the audience; same underlying process is a tricky question as i was explicitly trying to make sound and light eel like part of the same process;

payload.strategy: I aimed to draw from a longer/slower movement to something more frenetic then settle again. There appeared to be a two note combinations that produced scattershot bursts and I wanted to swap in and out of one.

payload.interference_notes: THe visual display felt much more crowded but less chaotic  - more structure perhaps? I was surprised by the lines runnig across the deck, and at one point there was a visual walk around the deck that I did not expect and did not hear in the sound whilst it was happening.
payload.expectation_vs_outcome: The visuals had a greater range of dense to sparse, and a greater range of patterning than expected. It seems like there are more rules or instances of notes visually than aurally. The visuals felt more graspable than my recollection of my control of the sounds but this might be reflection vs action.

payload.strategy: I could see a relationship between s few chords and the visual patterns they made, and hoped to progress through these - vertical lines, down right diagonals, clusters of 5. Some attempt to change the pace in an arc.

payload.interference_notes: The visual pattern did not match any auditory chonchordancy / harmony in any way that I would have predicted - they patterns of visuals and audio seem very separate. In addition, the pure tone perhaps meant that I could not hear the full complex nature of the sound that was clearly present and visible - perhaps because different octaves of the same note starting at the same time sounded as one. I could hear flurries of consecutive notes and perhaps different notes that coincided. I would be very interested to hear the outcome if these notes were more distinguishable, and likely would produce a much less busy piece!
payload.expectation_vs_outcome: The business of the sound did not seem to match the pattern or crowqding of the visuals. A number of sparse visuals sounded as busy as a previously very active visual. The visual patterning seemed to match dischordant sounds. and in some cases vice versa - a pleasant sound matching no visual pattern. A big mismatch overall.

payload.strategy: Aiming to oscillate between fullnes/complexity and simplicity/sparseness, but by different means - on one side using the life span / rate / neighbourhood rules, on the other side using the effect of harmonies and note availability.

payload.interference_notes: I am beginning to see why having neighbouring notes available results in simple repeating patterns and also dischordant sounds, and why having more harmony constrains the visuals under some game of life conditions, something about having the notes far enough away from each other meaning they are poor / unrelated neighbours. I think if I had better music theory I would understand this differently.
payload.expectation_vs_outcome: Less obvious visual structure than I expected but a stronger match between what I planned and what happened, and I feel like I am beginning to see a different and less obvious visual structure and how that relates to the sounds/notes. The two modalities are starting to feel linked in a way I didn't experience before. I had some inkling of this while playing but could see some impacts more clearly and unexpectedly in the review.

payload.one_change: Put the interface on one page without scrolling. Have nonlinear scales.
payload.reflection: The simplest patterns required local density - a repeating cluster or a line across the deck. This very fact of immediate neighbours translated to sound meant busy and unpleasant sounds. I was surprised at the lack of apparent relationship between the visual activity and the complexity of the sound and assume that this is in part because I could not distinguish a significant proportion of note pairings. The layout of the pattern of notes feels like it significantly hampers game of life creatures that sound nice, and I would be very interested in knowing about or playing with different layouts.
payload.session_notes_transcription: i get some of the mechanics of how this works but its chaotic; does the opposite of what i expect, not sure if thats due to the lack of visuals;(reset switch active) its not doing anything i want it to do (power of visual eedback to know whats going on - tricky in a audio only jaming situation to know what you are doing);more instances of visual notes than audible notes;i definataely feel like i understand the visuals more than the audio; pure sine wave might be making the perception of multiple notes harder - stacking of octves is getting perceived as a single note (could be due to the use of pure sine tones - consider using richer timbres for future work);overfitting of patterns to nice sounding chords (would expect a nice visual pattern to sound nice);

payload.interference_notes: I was quite suprised in how the sound/visual/speed fitted together, as I has no idea how it would sound when I was making it
payload.expectation_vs_outcome: quite surprising - much better than i thought it would be - didnt have th urge to turn it off after 15seconds, the connection between the audio and visuals isnt in my head - i had no idea how it was going to turn out but still quite please with how turned out

payload.one_change: No idea! But overall, it went better than I thought it would - I had no idea what to expect...
payload.reflection: It helps if you can hear the audio in your head while usinf the system.  I felt more in control when using both at the same time, but was pleased and a bit surprised with the result of the audio only piece
